Ah ok, I'm actually not certain from looking at it, but is this updating c-ares to 1.13.0? c-ares was upgraded to 1.13.0, which I believe is the version adding openbsd support, in #12305. This is on master but hasn't been released yet - it will exist in the grpc ruby gem in the 1.17.0 release.
@apolcyn I took master of grpc and it didn't have a new enough c-ares as submodule (the OpenBSD changes were missing). This commit upgrades it to the first version that does build.
BTW, this fixes #10411

@frenkel  I just verified and we are on 1.13 release commit of `c-ares` on gRPC `master`. We tend to only depend on release tags on the submodule repos and not any random commit point. I see that the commit you pointed `c-ares` submodule at is significantly older than what we are on. Can you ensure that your branch is up to date with gRPC `master`?

@frenkel  I just checked and your branch is not out of date. Please note that you are not upgrading `c-ares`—the one in use already is newer; did you intend to downgrade it? If the current c-ares does not build on OpenBSD, they should fix it in their repo and release a point release *on top of* their latest release before we can depend on it.
You're absolutely right, mix up on my side I guess. I've removed the commit and verified everything still builds correctly. Thanks!

I understand, but I don't know whether others need this. I'm not sure which
make is default on FreeBSD or NetBSD.
Sure. I'll update this PR tomorrow.

> I understand, but I don't know whether others need this. I'm not sure which make is default on FreeBSD or NetBSD.

NetBSD uses bmake (BSD make(1)), FreeBSD reuses it from NetBSD as is.
Updated this PR, didn't need to disable `-Werror` anymore and made the use of `gmake` work for all BSD's.
cc @nicolasnoble for taking a look at changes in `.h` and `.cc` files. (update: nevermind; verified carefully and the changes look benign.)
@apolcyn The changes LGTM contingent on tests passing. Can you please take a quick look for an additional sanity check?
